Jan 10 2008 	Very happy at the Mayflower	My husband and I stayed at the Mayflower for 5 nights, including New Years. We had a wonderful and wouldn't have picked another hotel. A little background: my husband and have lived in big cities including Atlanta, Chicago and San Francisco. My husband lived in the Russian Hill area of San Francisco for over 2 years just a few years ago.Now for the review: the hotel was very clean, including our room. When we checked in we were given a tour by the owner's (Nancy) husband. He showed all us all the different rooms, and gave us a choice of what room we wanted. It is a good idea to do this as all the rooms are bit different and you may find one you like more than another. For example, some rooms have newer refrigerators than others, different cabinetry, etc. They are in the (slow) process of remodeling the wet bar in each room and when they are all done they will look great! Currently, most of them are quite old, but still in good condition. We really enjoyed having a mini fridge and microwave in our room and was one of the many reasons we chose the Mayflower.We also picked a room on a higher floor, as the first and second floors are more open to street noise and are also colder. Since we went in the winter, we wanted to be warmer without using the heat (to avoid stuffiness). We kept the window open most of our stay and the noise was negligible. My husband sleeps with earplugs and is an extremely light sleeper and we both slept well. The bathroom fixtures are new, with old and neat bones still in place. The entire hotel is like this really, with the lovely features that old buildings have still in place, but modernized. We found the staff very helpful and friendly for the most part. Some of the night staff were kind of disinterested, but at that point we were heading to bed and really didn't care. The breakfast that some people raved about was just so-so in our opinion. It's great that they offer it, but we weren't impressed. It's a nice continental breakfast, don't expect more than that. We didn't, and weren't disappointed because of it. Previous reviewers were not kidding about the size of the garage. It is so narrow you have to see it to believe it. Our rental ford focus barely fit, and I mean by mere centimeters. We switched cars mid way through our stay and our Toyota Corolla was a better fit, but not by much. The garage has to be opened manually, and if you come and go frequently, it can be a bit annoying to stop and get out of the car, have someone open the garage and drive it down, but it's not that bad. Especially when you consider the price, the narrowness and slight inconvenience are all worth it.Our room's walk in closet had a funky odor, but I didn't find it obnoxious or offensive. I think it's just from being closed and not often used. Just sort of stale smelling. I hung my clothes in it and they didn't absorb any of the odor. The water pressure in our room was fine, we didn't find it weak at all. The linens were clean and very homey. The neighborhood is just fine. We came and went at all hours of the day and night and encountered no issues whatsoever. The hotel is near the area aslo known as the noberloin or tendernob, a blend of one of the sketchiest areas in SF and one of the ritziest. You turn one corner and you're in sketchville, you turn another and you're surrounded by high end restaurants and hotels. But the Mayflower is closer to the Nob than the Loin. The hotel is locked at night to make sure only guests enter. We walked to Union Square, and Nob Hill and I am in not such great shape, and it was not that bad. The previous poster who complained about the distance and hills - puhlease! If you like driving everywhere, go visit a suburb. We walked up two giant hills to get to Nob Hill and survived. It was fun. The area is good. And for the price, I would say the area is great. I think you would be hard pressed to find such a good deal any where else in the city.

Jan 6 2008 	Great budget hotel	I spent five days at the Mayflower. It's really a great option for less than a hundred dollars. The location is great, near Union Square and the room mas very big. Dec 3 2007 	Good If on a budget average for everything else.	Here is some background information before I jump on to the review. This past October, I traveled with a friend to San Francisco during the Canadian thanksgiving week-end and what coincided in San Francisco as Fleet week. The Blue Angels flew over the city a few times which was quite neat, although the public transit system downtown was overwhelmed, especially the cable car. Fact was, we learned that after booking our plane tickets and we were left hanging to find a decent hotel at a decent price. We're both university students in our early 20s and I'm pretty well traveled. Usually, I tend to select slightly plusher accomodation (thanks to a good job despite the student status), in the likes of Marriott, Hyatt, etc. Due to rates at 300$+ with limited availability, we booked the Mayflower for a night at 125$ for a "Superior room", 45$ more than their standard room, but that would apparently afford us a room higher up and with a view. Given how many people mentionned noise problems, we decided to upgrade. Bottom line, I have a good connection and we were lucky to move to the W for the last two nights. I'll break down the review in two sections, positives and negatives.POSITIVE:-True to the reviews here, Nancy, the owner, is a very nice and helpful lady. A younger Spanish speaking woman working that night was also very nice. That can't be said for the rest of the staff we encountered. -Hallway carpets looked brand new and so did he hallways in general. I agree, everything must have been painted quite recently. Room carpets looked maybe a little older but were still very clean.-Old style elevators but remodeled.-Very nice lobby, front desk and charming breakfast room with a very good continental breakfast included in the room rate, comprising breads, cereals, fruits and coffee/tea/juice/milk and finally yoghurt. -Plumbing related bathroom fixtures obviosuly brand new and no hot water problems.-Free WiFi a big plus. -Kitchenette with fridge and microwave helpful for longer stays.-Plenty of toiletries, including soap, shampoo, lotion and mouthwash.NEGATIVE:-The man who checked us in was a little sketchy and caught off guard smoking outside as we were walking in to register. They do not take credit card information at the time of reservation but will require payment at check-in rather than check-out, even when paying by credit card which I found odd. I asked to see the room first. I recommend you do the same. -Some staff members were rude, including the first gentleman who made the reservation for us over the phone. Completely disinterested.-The kitchenette's glassware was quite visibly unclean, the wine glasses in our room all had either lip gloss or fingerprints on them. -We did not think not having Air conditioning was going to be a problem early Oct. in SFO but given our room faced the sun all afternoon, it was stuffy in there. We therefore kept the window open and it was VERY noisy as a result, despite facing the back. The room did not cool down much before around 3 am when a bunch of drunks yelling woke us up.and we decided to close the window. Ceiling fan helped a bit but I get congested when sleeping with that running so shut it off in the middle of the night. -My bedspread and pillowcases had old blood stains on them. -Room cleanliness was so-so with dust clearly visible in corners and our walk-in had a stench which prevented from storing any luggage in there. -Bathroom, other than fixtures, is clean but old and the shower head as a result came right around the level of my forehead. I'm only 5'9. You can imagine my 6'3 friend had a lot of fun washing his hair in the morning. Took forever given the weak pressure. -The alleged view was pretty much non-existent, our room, despite being on the 5th floor, overlooked neighboring buildings that obstructed most of the view. -Mattresses are brand new (according to their tags) but both me and my friend found them uncomfortable due to firmness. This is more subjective though.-I would disagree the location being good or great. The neighborhood was not re-assuring at night. I would not walk there alone and I'm a guy. Not much around and pretty much everything requires a steep walk downhill or uphill, making transit use mandatory. Union Square is a good 10-15 minute walk. Bottom line, the location is O.K. Nothing more.Would I return to the Mayflower? Possibly If nothing else was available. Based on what I experienced, I can understand why people on a budget like it. It's a roof over your head with a breakfast included. I also thought the 45 additional dollars for a higher floor room was a waste of money, given the rooms lower were described on the phone as being virtually identical. The said view was non-existent and the room, just as noisy as that 80$ room probably was. I probably would have felt I got a better bang for my buck with that room type. If looking for a place to sleep that's relatively clean and safely guarded, accessible by public transit to most of SFO's attractions and cheap, the Mayflower will do it. If you're like us and like your comfort and convenience location-wise, they are wiser options.

Nov 19 2007 	Very good deal and very friendly! Going back there!!	The first week, we stayed at The Fairmont but, because of a major convention, we had to leave there and went to The Mayflower. Our room at The Mayflower was half the price of The Fairmont with many extras, including a garage for the car. We had free wireless ($14.95 a day at The Fairmont) and free continental breakfast ($33 for breakfast at The Fairmont). Quaint atmosphere and felt more like "old San Francisco", but very clean and neat. We will go back for another night before returning to China.

Nov 6 2007 	Great find for budget conscious travellers.	The Mayflower is an excellent find for those on a budget. I paid approx 40.00 a night for my room and it was more than adequate. The room was very big and plenty of storage of space. Shower was powerful and water always hot. Mattress was comfotable and room was very clean. Staff always pleasant and very helpful at check-in. If you are going to pick fault with it then I guess you could say it is in need of renovation. The buffets in the rooms are very old and do look a little tatty. The danger of renovating though is the price increase it would bring. Also the windows are originals, hence the noise from the street, which can become a disturbance. Free internet access is also a big PLUS. Always helpful to have this facility, especially when trying to make travel arrangements with other people you are trying to meet up with. Nice touch. One thing I will say is that the Lillies in reception are far too overpowering and would be nice if they were replaced with something else.

Oct 28 2007 	It had it's ups and downs	We enjoyed our stay overall but when we checked in we had some serious problems with the managers. Because of some miscommunication with the number of people traveling with us, we had too many people in the room. While the woman who was helping us was very helpful, the man who was also was there was unnecessarily rude and almost yelling at us. It is absolutely ridiculous how he was treating us and completely disrespectful. He was the only problem we had with the hotel, the rooms were big and the bathrooms were nice. I would recommend it as a budget hotel that you are using just for sleep. Great location.

Oct 21 2007 	Nice Hotel Good Price Great Staff	Stayed at the Mayflower with another couple. Two rooms between 3 of us. The hotel is situated in a very good location, near to Union Square, with a garage in the next block.The staff, Nancy and Nick, are friendly and extremely helpful. Rooms are clean, with two huge wardrobes, a very comfy bed and overall this "theme" hotel has a very cosy charm. It's not posh, but heck, it's not meant to be.At the prices offered, this is a really, really good deal - with breakfast (albeit simple) thrown in too.HIghly recommended, no complaints whatsoever. Just read the other reviews. This hotel is ranked in the top 50 out of 240 hotels in SFO, including the high end pricier posher ones. I guess that affirms my view.

Oct 3 2007 	Good hotel lots of character	This hotel was perfect for what we wanted. It had a central location, it was inexpensive and it had parking. It was very old and they were in the process of remodeling, it had lots of character, which made it fun. Nice beds, clean rooms, we would stay again.

Sep 26 2007 	Perfect!	Myself and my 2 friends stayed at The Mayflower for 3 nights in July and we were most impressed! The staff were all very friendly and when we arrived they gave us a map and told us where we should head to in the city and where the nearest bus/cable stops were - they even gave us a bottle of wine from the nearby Napa Valley to take to our room! The rooms were a good size, the beds were very comfortable and although there wasn't air con there was a large ceiling fan which was more than adequate... our room had a small kitchenette with a fridge and microwave and 2 very large walk in cupboards. Breakfast was basic but more than fine for the rate we paid. Location-wise this hotel is perfect, it is in a safe area and within walking distance to all the attractions in San Francisco. This is an old building but that adds to the charm! The lift in the reception area is particularly dinky! Oh and an added bonus was the computer area with free internet access.

Sep 14 2007 	Exactly what I wanted	I was visiting San Francisco for 3 days, primarily to see my son and go to a game at AT&T Park (the Diamondbacks won! yay!). His studio apartment wouldn't quite work for the two of us but I wanted to stay close. I couldn't get any closer as the Mayflower is literally the building next to his apartment building. This was a cool old building with a very nice lobby and loft/mezzanine. The staff made me feel right at home. This is an historic building that while serviceable was not what I would describe as renovated. It was clean and comfortable, though, and it would be a tragedy if this place was brought to its full potential and turned into a trendy boutique hotel that cost $300 a night. Some might find the street-facing rooms a little noisy. I would/will certainly stay here again.

Sep 3 2007 	Great value 	Chosen on Tripadviser recommendations. Excellent place and very friendly and helpful staff, especially Nancy. Even returned things we had left behind. Difficult to believe that the combination of location and price can be beaten. Great sandwiches next door.

Aug 29 2007 	Better than expected for the price	I didn't get off to a good start here, as my rental Chevy Impala wouldn't fit through their garage doors. But it all picked up after that. The staff was very friendly, my room looked like it had been recently painted -- as did the corridors -- which is good in a building as old as this one. (The elevators are the kind that require you to open the door to get out.) My room had a small kitchenette with a tiny fridge, microwave, a sink, counter space, a couple of plates, a couple of bowls, and a fork. (Not sure what you would put in a bowl that you can eat with a fork.) No A.C., but there was a ceiling fan. That was fine. I got a room on the "quiet" side -- and it was, even though the Mayflower is in the heart of the city, between Union Square and Nob Hill. For those not real familiar with Nob Hill, if you're going to Grace Cathedral, be warned that the 2 blocks between the Mayflower and the Cathedral are about the steepest blocks you'll ever see. The Powell-Hyde cable car, which is good for getting around, is a quick 3 blocks away. The Mayflower offers a complimentary breakfast of sorts, which seems increasingly common in hotels/motels. Muffins, packaged cheese, coffee, bananas, orange juice, milk, cereal....Price for 2 nights was $175 total. Absolutely no complaints, and would stay there again. But I'll rent a smaller car next time.

Aug 2 2007 	Nice Place	The Hotel Mayflower is a great place to stay with children. The room we had offered a full-size bed and a twin trundle. The room was very clean, and the no a.c. didn't bug us because the weather was cool and the ceiling fans did the trick. We loved the multiple closets our room offered, it allowed us to stay tidy and stash stuff during our stay. Parking was handy...plenty big once you get down into the garage, but beware, the driveway is extremely narrow. This place is old, old, old...but we found the hotel gave us some real San Francisco flavor. The location is perfect, close to everything. Staff was attentive and friendly. You can't beat it for the price...especially including a light breakfast each day...NICE!

Jul 30 2007 	A great friendly hotel	The staff here were really friendly and were very helpful. They told us were to go and where not to go. The rooms are clean and a good size. Our room contained two large cupboards, a microwave and a 'fridge. The property is old and is not your modern day fancy hotel - but this adds to the charm. check out the old fashioned elevators!It is centrally located and within walking distance of most things. The breakfast is a simple buffet and quite basic - but fine.If I were to stay in San Francisco I would definitely stay here again.

Jul 17 2007 	Wonderful staff	We stayed at this hotel this month and were so impressed with the wonderful staff. The Hotel was very nice with decent sized rooms, a huge walk in wardrobe, kitchenette with microwave, fridge and sink, spacious bathroom with beautiful toiletries. The Bed was a double, very comfortable with equally comfortable pillows. The breakfast was very nice and we (4 People) were all very happy with our selection. The rooms was very clean and housekeeping was fast and efficient. We found all of the staff to be excellent and the owners were such lovely people we almost felt that we were friends staying in their home. I can't recommend this hotel highly enough. It isn't 5 star if that is what you are looking for but if like us you like something clean, comfortable and affordable then you should give this one a try.

Jul 12 2007 	The worst hotel experience of my life!	My husband and I booked a room at the Hotel Mayflower for the last two nights of our California vacation. We chose the Mayflower because the picture of the lobby looked nice, it was cheap, and we had been splurging on pricier rooms for most of our trip. We checked in and went to check out our room - we we're very disappointed with everything beyond the lobby. It's like an old senior apartment building. It smelled like a nursing home and the bed looked 25 years old - with a dip in the middle of the mattress. Oh well, we'd make due I thought. We went back to the car to get our luggage and when we returned, the front door was locked. I rattled the doorknob, my husband pushed on the other side, I was going to ring the buzzer, but looked in and saw someone coming to the door. He peeked out and said "Did you kick the door? You kicked the door. Find another motel, I don't want you here." And then he slammed the door. I thought it was a joke at first, or he was a crazy resident, or even that it was a scam to get our money. Turns out he was legitimately kicking us out for allegedly kicking the door. It was insane! Here we had paid for our room, and we're struggling to the door with all our luggage and IT"S LOCKED. Do you think we could perhaps be offered some HELP from the staff for goodness sake. NO, we're locked out and then KICKED OUT !We were dumbfounded and quite angry for being treated so rudely , but agreed we'd never dream of staying there after being treated this way anyways and so we waited for them to refund our credit card and left quietly. We SO wanted to kick the door for real on the way out!This story has a happy ending. We found a MUCH NICER hotel a few blocks away - Hotel Carlton- The staff was kind, the decor was new, everything was clean, even valet parking for only $20 more a night!

Jul 5 2007	Great Location	Great location to everything in the city, only a few blocks away from the cable car. Free bottle of wine at check-in, cheap parking but a tight fit in the garage. Staff was great at giving directions. Definitely will stay there again if I get back to the city.

Jun 29 2007 	A great hotel.	We found the Hotel Mayflower to be a well run establishment with friendly and helpfull staff. The room rates are very reasonable and well equipped with fridge, air con and en suite bathroom with shower and bath. On arrival all guests get a bottle of wine. There is undergroung parking available for approx 10 cars which was provided to us free of charge. It is a very tight space and SUV's may struggle but no problem for the average saloon car. There is free internet access with three computers available for use by guests. Literatue and advice is freely available in the Hotel. Bush Street is only 10 mins walking from the heart of the city and Trams, Buses and taxi's are even closer. This is a great Hotel on a budget.

Jun 27 2007 	Hotel is a personal choice	I stayed at the Hotel Mayflower in March 2007, after reading all the excellent reviews on TripAdvisor about the hotel. Yes, I totally agree with all the good comments. Staff were friendly and attentive, even with her limited English the housekeeping staff took very good care of me. The location is fantastic, except Bush Street could be a problem if you are a light sleeper. Breakfast was complete (considering the room rate) The hotel is not of five-star class, but with basic necessities and great location. However, I believe hotel is a personal choice for everyone. I like the hotel, but it's not my cup of tea. I'm a regular to San Francisco and the reason for travelling is to socialise and get to know people, but this hotel didn't offer me the chance to do so, as much as the other hotels I've stayed during my previous visits.

Jun 18 2007 	Not Bad But Not Great Either	My wife, son and I stayed at the Mayflower June 11-14. We arrived a few hours early, the clerk let us keep our bags there while we went out exploring. That was a nice gesture. When we arrived at our room, however, we were put in a one bed room, when we clearly booked a 2 bed room months ago. That caused some tepidation. But the manager was called and made it right, giving us the first night free. I can understand why guests do not like being on the Bush Street side of the hotel. That street is very loud and alot of traffic. The room we stayed in had no air conditioning and in the 80 degree weather we experienced, we were very warm all night. Thank God for the ceiling fan Many reviewers mentioned the friendly staff. We did not experience this. The clerks went about their business, but were never friendly, and a couple clerks kind of glowered at us when we would first enter the lobby. Two asked us what our business was in the lobby, and we had to tell them we were guests in their hotel. I didn't care for their tone. The breakfast was meager. It looked like they went next door and bought bread and peanut butter and instant oatmeal. It was very plain and no imagination at all. One day after returning back to our room after a day in the 90 degree weather, the housekeeper had turned our ceiling fan off. The room never did cool down. Also, the cable was very basic, and a few channels were always very fuzzy. But you get what you pay for. We never felt unsafe, and we did get to keep our bags at the hotel when we first arrived. Plus, we were reembursed for the first day miscommunication, which was a plus. Would I come back again? Only if I couldn't get a hotel closer to the Wharf.

May 7 2007	Great value for the price!	This hotel is so cute and has an old world charm. It's been renovated to its original architecture. You cannot beat the price and the hospitality. I only paid $80 for a one bedroom w/ two double beds and a kitchenette. It's not far to walk from Bart and the neighborhood is totally safe. It was very clean as well. I highly recommend it and would definitely come back!

May 2 2007 	What a Fantastic Find!	My husband wanted to take a "low-budget" weekend trip to San Francisco for our first anniversary & being the "Deal-finder" I am, I tracked down the Mayflower. For only $80 I was a little scared of where we'd end up. What a fantastic surprise! Some of the highlights:- Wonderful staff, very friendly & helpful- Great location... walking distance to Union Square- Safe, clean neighborhood- Free high-speed Internet access in room- Continental breakfast (toast, muffins, oatmeal, juice, coffee, etc.)- Free basic cable- On-site parking (if you have a small car) usually cheaper than public garages- Spacious, clean rooms (with a kitchenette)- Refrigerator, microwave and nice bath ammenities- We got a complimentary bottle of a great red wine when we checked in- Extremely safe... the doors were locked at night and we had to be buzzed in (with ID)The hotel is very charming and historic, but still very clean. My very "anti-city" husband felt safe & comfortable both in the hotel and the surrounding area. The rooms are not luxurious or fancy, but If you are looking for a great deal on a fantastic, authentic SF hotel- this place can't be beat. We'll definitely go back!

Apr 27 2007 	Worth more than you pay for!	i stayed here a couple of weeks ago. nice clean hotel with great helpful staff! before you book your room though, make sure your heater/aircon is working in the room. the room i booked had a really weak heater and it was very cold in the morning. thank god the beddings were warm. also, ask for a room away from the main street. at 430am, you can hear the street cleaners trucks which really woke me up. otherwise, if you're on a budget but don't want to stay in a hostel, i highly recommend this place. i would stay here again.

Apr 26 2007 	Great price great location	Chose this hotel based on reviews and the price. $80 for a quiet room with a double bed, TV with basic channels, small kitchenette w/ fridge, microwave, and dishes, and a huge closet. It also included a basic continental breakfast with coffee, tea, oj, oatmeal, bread, fruits, baked goods. Front desk was helpful, we were able to check-in at an earlier time, and when we checked out, we were able to store our luggage for a few extra hours. There was wi-fi access, as well computers which helped us plan our trip around SF.Location was great!!! Quite close to the cable cars and MUNI stops. Be careful if you don't know your way around, did manage to wander into Tenderloin area while exploring on our first day. Did feel safe, doors are locked after a certain time, and we just buzz in to get back into the hotel after a long night out :)

Apr 19 2007 	a great deal for the price	I stayed at the Mayflower after reading the good reviews on Trip Advisor and getting a great rate for the week. The room was only $80 per night, which is very low for San Francisco. For that price, we had a relatively nice and clean room on the 5th floor of the hotel. Our room faced onto Bush Street which can be noisy in the morning, so request a room on the other side of the building if that that may be an issue you. The location of the hotel is fantastic. If you don't mind climbing a steep hill, the California Street cable car line is only two blocks away, providing easy access to the financial district and the Ferry Building. It is also only two or three blocks from the Powell street line, which goes to Chinatown and Fisherman's Wharf. Union Square is within easy walking distance as are many restaurants and cafes. The Mayflower is next door to a small market and deli, which was extra convenient since my room had a small kitchenette with a refrigerator. If you don't wake up in time for the continental breakfast (coffee, juice and toast) it is nice to have access to your own refrigerator. Another bonus is that the hotel has its own parking garage. Many hotels in the city charge guests up to $35 per day, but the Mayflower only charged me $10 even though they quoted $20. This included in/out privileges, but you must ask the front desk attendant to open the garage for you as the door is not automatic. The only warning is that the garage is very small. Not only are the spaces small, but the entrance to it is very small as well. Definitely don't plan on parking here if you have an SUV, or even anything larger than our Civic. Overall, the Mayflower is a great hotel. If you don't expect a 5-star room, you will be pleased with the free wireless access and cute details of a quirky old building. Definitely, the price is good for such a great location.

Apr 1 2007 	Old yet familiar	This was a wonderful choice it was very resonable and the access to the area is just great. Being on top of one of the hills in San Francisco gives you a great view from Bush St down to the Financial District. Plus it is a short walk to Grant which is where China Town is. The proximity to Tenderloin was a concern until I realized that it was far enough up that the undesirable elements wouldn't go so far as to get this location. The Staff is wonderful they let me in every night since I stayed out and they were very helpful. I was able to even check in at 12 Pm. There is art in all the hallways in this beautifully decorated hotel. The street noise can be a bit much. I did speak the manager about this and she said that the city would not let her change them to double pained windows because it was historic. After all that walking getting to sleep isn't much of a problem.

Nov 18 2009 	Valentine's Day	I love this city and this trip! The hotel was great, guess which celebrity room we stayed in?

Nov 16 2009 	Great hotel - highly recommended!	The excellent staff and comfortable stay at Hotel Triton were highlights of our trip to San Francisco. Every one of the staff we encountered was incredibly friendly and willing to help out in any way possible.The room we stayed in (an Eco Premier King Room) was nicely furnished with plenty of room and was very quiet. Some of the fittings (mainly in the bathroom) were a little bit dated but everything was very clean and in good condition. There's free wi-fi throughout the hotel and a free (pretty basic) fitness room in the basement. The free daily wine reception is a great opportunity to sit around and have a chat to the staff and other guests.The location of Hotel Triton is good in that it's within easy walking distance of Chinatown and Union Square. Muni Metro, BART, the F-line streetcar and Powell cable car line are all within a five minute walk so it's easy to get anywhere in the city and to/from the airport via BART.We'll definitely be heading back to Hotel Triton on our next visit to SF - it's great value and I honestly can't think of one bad thing to say about our experience there!

Nov 11 2009 	What a find!	A group of friends and I went to San Francisco to celebrate my birthday and I chose to stay at Triton because of it's funky look and the Kimpton brand. Although I knew I'd have a great stay, I was still blown away by the amazing service, great location and unique and funky atmosphere. Every staff member I encountered was friendly and accommodating. The location couldn't have been better, we were steps away from great restaurants, shops and China Town. They made a fuss over my birthday and even gave me a birthday gift! The rooms are a bit small, but this hotel has so much heart that it more than makes up for it. I work in the hospitality industry and wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel to anyone.

Nov 11 2009 	Quirky little hotel in great location	SummaryGreat little hotel with fun freebies like wine tasting and cookies. Rooms are small with no views but it's location is great and service very friendly and helpful.LocationRight at the China Gate you can walk to North Beach, Exchange Square, even to Mission though it's very close to subway. Valet is $35 a night but its not really any cheaper elsewhere.RoomsSmall and very small windows so bit dark but quirkily decorated and perfectly clean and comfortable. Tiny bathroom, again though clean and fineServiceFriendly and helpfulBar and RestaurantThe cafe next door is the bar and restuarant where we had some great cocktails but didn't eat. However our friends who live in San Fran said its's a great cafe. Breakfast is an odd affair with oj and a muffin delivered to your room in a paper bag but you have to pop downstairs if you want coffee (free in the lobby). Make sure one day though that you pop round the corner for the world famous pancakes!!

Oct 23 2009 	Great location and really friendly and helpful staff	I love staying at Kimpton Hotels when I travel. I picked this one in San Francisco because I knew it would be in a busy area of town with lots of restaurants. It was a great choice. I went for some great morning runs over the San Francisco hills over to Fisherman's Wharf. I loved being by Chinatown and also being close to the BART station. I booked a ZipCar that was parked a half a block away. The staff helped me find the kind of restaurants I wanted to eat at... in fact, the kindly answered all my questions (how to take the BART, how to get here and there.) The room was small but cute and the hotel feels like an old building brought up-to-date with modern amenities. I love ending each day with a free glass of wine in the lobby.

Oct 6 2009 	Very pet friendly cool decor and free wine happy hour...what more to ask for?? oh right by chinatown	I booked this hotel after finding a great price online in planning for a west coast roadtrip. It had decent reviews and had never statyed there. Traveling with a pet kinda makes it complicated in finding decent hotels that accept dogs (real dogs, above 12 pounds; mine's about 55 lbs). It was in a great location right across from the welcome gate to Chinatown, had a great room rate, accepted pets, so I booked it right away for three nights.Only downfall (although I didn't see it as such since I was on vacation and having been to the city before knowing on street parking is at a premium) was the price for the garage parking provided by the hotel. I believe it was $20 a night. I wanted to spend my time in other pursuits than searching for a parking spot. But my truck was available for me to use or get stuff out that I had forgotten to take out with just a phone call. It was pretty convenient and well worth the cost to eliminate any vehicle parking hassles.The hotel staff was very friendly upon check-in. I brought my dog in and they put her name on the "pets at the hotel" chalkboard on the front desk visible for all. Although, she can't read, i'm sure she was proud to be recognized. And being a nice dog, everybody loved her when she was in the elevator, hallways and front lobby by guests and staff alike.The decor was very upbeat and cheery throughout the hotel.The room was kinda small for two people and a dog, but really on vacation, a room is just a bed to sleep in and any niceties are a plus (just my opinion). BUT the room was very well maintained and clean with all the amenities (flat screen TV). Very comfortable and a nice bed (queen) as well. Decent toiletries soap and shampoo and such that aren't like the cheap scrub your skin off and leave you dry and bleeding soaps at the right off the interstate sketch hotel soap. Very nice to take a shower and use the products provided.All in all, this place is pretty cool, hip and a in a great location. Right by the BEST chinese food you could ever get in the country! Great stay and would definitely stay again.

Oct 2 2009 	Great place to stay!	I shopped all over the downtown/ Union Sq. area and really wanted to stay at a Kimpton hotel but was having to stay within the budget of my company. I decided on Hotel Triton and was not disappointed! I checked in late and had not had dinner. I had many snack options from the well stocked mini bar! The room did smell a little musty but it is an older building. It wasn't overwhelming but it was noticeable. But....that will not stop me from staying there again. I just checked out this morning and have already made 3 new reservations for my business trips in the coming weeks. EXCELLENT location and very clean. This is my new "go-to" hotel in San Fran!

Sep 27 2009 	a quirky little room steps from Chinatown and Union Square	Upon walking in the hotel, the staff was extremely pleasant, kind and happy to see me. The lobby is quite spacious for a boutique hotel and every night they have a complimentary wine hour from 5pm to 6pm. The hotel is located just steps away from the Chinatown arches and a few short blocks from Union Square. At night, the neighborhood felt very safe and, during the day, it is a bustling area with many dining options and plenty of shopping. My room, on the 3rd floor, was very small. Everything just fit in the room: the queen bed, the TV, drawers, desk and 2 bed tables. The bathroom was very small and the closet space was pretty average. But, it didn't matter. I just needed a place to sleep and take a shower so I wasn't looking for anything fancy. Everything was very clean and I slept soundly in the very comfortable bed. Also, the rate was excellent and I feel like I got my money's worth at this hotel.I have only one complaint.: The ventilation was not very good. I needed to keep the air conditioner on the entire time and it was not particularly humid. It's San Francisco and simply opening the windows provides natural air conditioning. Unfortunately that wasn't an option because the AC unit was located in the only window. Also, one strange thing I noticed was that the fire emergency instructions, located on the inside of the front door, were upside down. Fortunately, there was no fire and I didn't have to stand on my head to read how to safely exit the building!Overall, a nice little hotel but, if you need a lot of space, make sure to check directly with the hotel to make sure you are getting a big room. I think they do have a few larger rooms but most of them are tiny like mine was. Also, try to get a room with a couple windows that open so that you have good ventilation.

Sep 25 2009 	A great hotel for someone travelling alone	I stayed here during July for 5 nights. It was my very first time in the US and since I am coming from Europe I was really worried of what to expect in terms of quality, service and of course safety in my hotel and room since I was travelling on my own.The first impression was the best. Very polite and typical at the same time people in the reception.The room was exactly like the pictures I have seen and they cleaned it every day.The location in San Francisco was perfect, around 5-10 min from everything important downtown.No homeless people around in the evening but of course I didn't return back after 22.00.Totally a good hotel maybe a little expensive for a solo traveler but I always prefer to spend something more and not having to worry about my stuff,my mood etc.If I return to San Fransisco one day I would definetely stay here again.

Sep 12 2009 	Great Location and Staff	The hotel was a pleasant surprise. The "hip" theme scared me a bit, but basically, it was a neat, clean hotel in a wonderful location. The staff was friendly and professional, the room was very clean and comfortable. I particularly appreciated the filtered water. No need to run to Walgreens for bottled water.The only negative I can think of - please, take out all the overpriced items from the fridge. All I want is a small fridge to store a few items. When I return next year, I hope to find and empty fridge. Do that and I would consider this hotel one of my top picks in San Francisco.

Sep 4 2009 	They used window-type air-conditioners!	My travel agent asked me to go for this Triton Hotel because the neighbouring Marriott hotels were found full 2 days before the start of my business trip and I settled for it accordingly, as it was only for one night "transit" stay.The hotel location is convenient and the staff friendly, the common areas and the rooms are slightly worn out but acceptable.The main problem is that the rooms are equipped with "window-type" air-conditioning units which are noisy when operating, and gives no fresh air. [N.B.: Travellers who read this review may trust my judgement as I have been belonging to the property discipline for many years.]After switching on the units at night for 2 hours, the room becomes nothing but noisy and stuffy, lacking oxygen. To open the windows for fresh air means 2 other problems: firstly, my room (and may be half of the rooms in such hotel) faces the side lane where the refuse rooms of the hotel and other adjoining buildings are located and can catch such "unforgettable" smell; secondly, the service vehicles and refuse-collection vehicles in US operate at nights, with their dumping and travelling noises throughout the night-time.So, the result is: "shallow-sleeping people" like me cannot sleep.Fortunately, it was only for one night stay, and I presume I would not be returning again unless they install some centralized ventilation system with treated air.One point worth mentioning: the hotel's web-page didn't show any "window-type" air-conditioning units in any of their rooms' interior photos, and "experienced people" like me would return to the website and find from the exterior night-view photo some ideas of the "window-type" air-conditioning units along the dim facades. I wished I had noticed those "window-type" air-conditioning units before I agreed to my travel agent's former offer.

Jul 27 2009 	Trendy hotel rooms a bit underwhelming Nice staff.	Stayed at the Kimpton for a Hematology meeting in late 2008. A bit of "old guy" smell. that dissappeared with running the AC. he hotel is sort of interesting in that it seems like they took an OLD building and funkied it up. One thing I enjoyed was the "happy hour" where red wine was served and a bunch of us hung out in the lobby. Pretty limited seating though.The location is very good. Next to the Chinatown gates and near some shopping "Ugg" "Banana Republic" etc. It was quiet and safe. Nearby 7 eleven and a reasonably close starbucks. There was a high end breakfast place on the corner that looked good but overpriced. Only a couple of blocks from Union Square and Macy's and Victoria's secret.Overall a decent hotel. Much cheaper than say the Westin but in my opinion you don't get as much. Happy travelling.

Jul 23 2009 	I will stay here whenever I can!	We loved the Triton for its helpful and friendly staff; the cute, clean and quiet room, and the central location. We were able to walk all over The City from there. We hadn't had a vacation in some time and this helped make our trip great.

Jul 16 2009 	Funky fun hotel in a fantastic location!	I have wanted to stay at this hotel for years and finally got the chance on a two-night stay with my 11-year-old son in San Francisco on the 11th and 12th of July.Love the decor of this place...it's not your run-of-the-mill hotel! Cartoonish wallpaper, metallic fabrics on the furniture, Michael Jackson videos on the flatscreen, and rubber duckies in the fountain...you know you're in for something different as soon as you pull up.We paid $143 a night with an additional $38 charge per day for parking. I have stayed in nearly every major city in the world and have never paid this much for parking. I did feel that the price of the room was VERY fair compared to other San Francisco hotels of similar quality.Our room (208) was a second floor, corner room directly across from the southernmost Chinatown gate and Starbucks. Great view! My only complaint is that this room, being a corner on a lower floor, was very loud on Saturday night. We were awakened numerous times by very loud, partying people (well after midnight) and traffic. Sunday night was better...we heard no people and turned on the AC unit for some white noise. I didn't ask to move rooms on the second night because I really didn't want to move for just one night - but potential guests should be aware of this if they want to get some sleep.Other than that the stay was outstanding! The room was very comfortable and I was impressed at how this older hotel had been redone to serve modern needs. Great flatscreen for watching movies, comfortable bed, interesting art and decor, and a very nice sink area with lovely amenities. The honor bar is exorbitantly expensive!! I know that all hotels charge crazy amounts for in-room snacks but $3.50 for a Snickers bar and $6 for a bottle of water is just stupid. This hotel is an easy walk from Chinatown (literally right across the street), Union Square, the Financial District, and the Embarcadero/Market Street area. A bus stops right outside the hotel and the Muni is a short walk away.They have a fantastic little French bistro next door that has some of the best croissants I've had outside France. I loved that complete selection of French-language magazines for sale and getting a chance to practice my French with our waiter! Such good coffee - I was a little hesitant to stay here with my son thinking that such a funky hotel would be full of youngish people trying to look hip and pick up on each other...there was some of this but there were also plenty of older people, families, musicians, and regular folk staying. I felt very comfortable staying here with my son!I will certainly stay here again when I come to San Francisco - it's a good value for this city.The staff is great - they always greeted my son and I by name

Jul 13 2009 	hidden gem	The hotel is in a good location, just few block from Union Square. In the morning you can get Tea or Coffee and at 5pm you can get some wine (white and red).The room size is good for an hotel in the city.

Jun 26 2009 	Location (by the Chinatown gates) Friendly Staff - Perfect Spot	The location, directly by the Chinatown gates, was just right because it makes the hotel one of the easiest to find in the city. It was a quick walk from the hotel to the 30 bus which you can take to skip the Chinatown mobs and get to other parts of the city. When we arrived on Thursday late afternoon, we checked in with the nicest front desk attendant. He was able to give us a recommendation for Thai food nearby, at OSHA. We took his suggestion and found the place to be just as he described - no frills but great food and fast service. The room we were assigned was just two doors down from the Kathy Griffin suite and because we're both big fans of the D List, we were pretty enchanted every time we walked by the door. I'm a terribly light sleeper but was never awakened by noise because our room was facing the courtyard. It was utterly silent every night - thank you, Hotel Triton. The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was clean and small but perfectly sufficient. We also had pretty fast internet connection via the free Kimpton rewards wifi. The coffee service in the mornings was free which is an amenity that is hard to find lately. Moreover, the coffee was tasty and strong and there was soy milk in addition to milk and cream. I would be sold on the coffee service alone. I have absolutely no complaints. This was the perfect hotel for a young couple from the East coast, like my husband and myself. Everyone working in the hotel was beyond helpful: from the cleaning person on our floor, to the valet at the door, to the front desk attendants, to the wine hour host.

Jun 23 2009 	Fun hotel - great location	My husband and I stayed at Triton over Memorial Day weekend. Normally when in San Francisco we stay at my in-laws, but they were having some work done at their place so we got a hotel instead. We decided on a Kimpton Hotel due to the great experiences we have had with them in the past, and Hotel Triton was no exception.We reserved a Queen room and were upgraded to one of their Organic Haven rooms at check in. The room was small but that was to be expected in such a central city location. The closet was a good size and there was a wardrobe for storage as well. The bathroom was small but serviceable, with a nice shower and plenty of shelves for storage of products. The room also had a source book for all of the organic materials that went into it as well as a guest book signed by previous occupants that was fun to read.The staff was beyond friendly and helpful, and like all Kimpton Hotels there was an evening complementary wine hour from 5 - 6 pm where all guest gathered in the lobby and relaxed on the couches and drank wine. There was a lot to see and do in the area as well as easy access to BART, buses, and cable cars.

Jun 20 2009 	Wonderful location nice hotel	I took a 4-day weekend getaway to San Francisco in April 2009. Doing various web searches for budget-style hotels (I'm typically a budget traveler, even staying in hostels around the world), I found the Hotel Triton to have an incredible sale. For ~$100 / night, I figure I couldn't go wrong considering the truly great location in central S.F.I wasn't wrong. Triton fulfills some major requirements that I look for in hotels: Proximity to public transit to/from airport (only a few blocks walk from Montgomery St. BART Station and even close to cable cars and certainly many bus lines), price, and wireless Internet (it's even free). It's central location is the major bonus for me. The hotel is a small-ish boutique hotel right across the street from the Gates of Chinatown, and within walking distance of North Beach, the Financial District, Tenderloin, etc. It is a bit of a haul on the electric trolley or Muni to the Castro - but I only went to the Castro once or twice. Most of my time was spent sightseeing the central areas of the city, and happy hours in North Beach (Vesuvio is an absolute must).Yes, my room was small and my window looked onto an alley - though I didn't spend much time in my room. I was visiting San Francisco to explore the wonderful city, not the insides of a hotel room. In fact, the staff let me bring a bike that I had rented into my room for safety. The afternoon wine reception was nice (and free), though the wines were, of course, not the best quality (read: free).One complaint - the 2nd day I was there, the maid did not replace my bath towels. I only had one towel out of 2 left. Not the end of the world, but I had rented the bike and needed to shower when I was done with riding for the day (riding up and down those hills can make a guy sweaty), so I had to use my last towel to shower that evening and then use the same one the next morning.All-in-all, as a solo traveler/explorer, I would absolutely stay at the Triton Hotel again, given the price.

Jun 17 2009	Fun 	Adorable! Jun 4 2009 	Understated and fuss-free...a gem	Our exerience at the Triton was unreservedly a good one. The staff were extremely friendly and helpful without being horribly pushy/over-familiar. We took advantage of the free tea and coffee in the morning (which was a real bonus to anyone who finds Starbucks coffee weak and unpleasant) but were always too busy to partake of the evening wine tasting. Sure, it was a wee bit basic-looking, but I wasn't in SF to sit about in a hotel room.The hotel is perfectly situated for some serious shopping (some of it very high-end, if that's your thing) - it's close enough to dump your first haul of the day before going out for round two!Cafe de la Presse next door did a good hearty breakfast, but here's a tip for those of you who can't take a big meal first thing - we would often trot down to the Westfield Centre on Market Street and buy a yogurt from the Bristol Farms store in the basement, and a Peets coffee to accompany it. May 4 2009 	Great location but "shabby chic" takes on a new meaning here	You can't ask for a better location than the Triton - right across from Chinatown Gate! As we drove through the night and then spent the entire day walking our feet off in the city prior to checking in, the Triton provided just the comfort and fun atmosphere we craved. True bliss!Crazy-bright decor and furniture in the lobby with complimentary wine in the late afternoon and good coffee in the morning, a bustling cafe next door and a Starbucks across the street, the entrance to Chinatown a few steps away, and helpful staff on reception at all hours made our stay most memorable.The hotel also has a good location, within walking distance to many highlights, and close to public transportation. Usually we object to the high cost of valet parking in the city and choose to leave our car in the Union Square underground parking garage and walk to our hotel, but this time we made the right decision, leaving our car with the Hotel Triton valet staff. For only a couple of dollars more (plus tip which they deserved!), our car was whisked away, in an out privileges were available (not available at Union Square at the less expensive 24-hour rate), and they even let us park outside the hotel on the street for a little longer so we could walk to the Museum of Modern Art area where it's really hard to find parking. We really appreciated their concern and assistance.My daughter also loved the Triton rubber ducks floating in the fountain at the entrance. Nice touch! We enjoyed sipping coffee in the lobby in the morning, watching people discovering the ducks with amusement as they walked by. Good photo opportunities!We highly recommend the Hotel Triton, and will stay there again.Tip: The cafe next door has great chocolate croissants, and the main street of Chinatown has endless eating opportunities.

Jun 9 2008	Triton is tops	I already liked Kimpton properties for their small, unique boutique approach to hotels. Every time I step into the room of one the major chains I feel like a little of my soul disappears. Hence, I'll take interesting personality over bland uniformity even if the former means the occasional surprise.A surprise we were handed at the Triton recently when our stay was going dandy until our car was "trapped" by a broken door at the offsite garage the Triton uses for valet. But how the Triton staff did backflips to deal with situation was the real and rare delight. Our vacation didn't miss a beat as they found us cabs (and paid for them), comped meals and the valet charges. I imagine they could charge some of these expenses back to the garage, but even if they had to eat some they, in exchange, got a customer for life.And one willing to write his 1st TripAdvisor review ever. Even without the above incident-turned-delight, our stay at the Triton was terrific. Fun rooms, killer lobby, entertaining staff, nifty SF locale, fair price too. Plus, we love Kimpton's real deal sustainable business practices.

Jun 4 2008 	Fabulous Hotel -Great Location Staff Rooms!	Hotel Triton in San Francisco is one of the Kimpton hotels --and when you stay at one of the Kimpton hotels, it's never a dull experience. Jun 2 2008 	Awesome Hotel	This hotel is absolutely wonderful! I loved the different look of the hotel. May 27 2008 	Nice but different experience	We spent 4 days at the Triton Hotel and enjoyed our stay very much.The hotel has many unusual features compared to other hotels we have stayed with such as the "wine hour" and the decor.If we had anything to complain about it would have to be the garbage trucks every night at all hours of the night.I am not faulting the hotel as we are sure they have little or no control over this matter.Hotel staff was wonderful.We received help from Tim,Anthony,Melissa and Tommy and they all were very pleasant.

May 21 2008 	Best hotel stay ever!	I named my price from priceline.com and received the Hotel Triton as one of my options. May 3 2008 	tack o rama	I am writing this from the Hotel. I will come update it if there is need. My husband wanted to try somethong new and quirky for our friends 26th birthday (we usually stay at the mark hopkins) so we chose the Hotel Triton, because we had walked by and knew its in a GREAT location, and its a kimpton and weve stayed at The Hotel Monaco in Seattle many times...So we get two "Celebrity Suites" I think they are $359 per night each. After viewing the rooms online, we request the King Triton suite and the Hagen Daz suite....So we get to the hotel at 11pm or so and check in, it is me my husband and one memmber of the other party. The guy was really nice and told us all about where to eat and drink nearby, and the lobby is cute and they have rubber duckies ion the fountain. So the three of us and the hotel worker go up to our room (the other room comes later) and we get in the King Triton suite (supposedly the BEST room they have) and it REEKS like smoke....and someone had put plastic wrap all over the smoke detector...so he brings us air freshener and opens the windows (which look out on some weird wooden scary platform and other rooms) anywayz the room is BEYOND tacky (i have stayed at an adult theme motel before....and really it was better) there are mirrors everywhere, and a bright red light in the tub room (also tub is small one person jacuzzi like the size youd have in your bathroom at home). Also as we walk down to meet the other person, we start to nitoce more and more how the whole hotel is so obviously a former crack motel that they tried hard to make pretty...sagging floors, peeling wallpaper and paint....dirt in weird spots...weird staircases...So its like 1145 now and our friend has parked in front of the hotel and is getting out....we all walk back in. No employees in sight, finally my husband searches one out, and they check her in...she has the hagen daz suite....we go into check it out...MUCH BETTER ROOM than the kinf tritin suite.....much newer and much more care put in (still some uneven paint etc) has very cute fully stocked (free) freezer....the bed rattles tho every time you move even a bit....definitely a nicer room though....so she realizes the pillows are all down and she needs foam...we take the elevator of hell (it randomly goes to unrequested floors and stops) down to ask for some....."sorry we gave them all away" were told. And thats where we are so far.....more later....

Apr 12 2008 	Fun 	I love this place - it was so fun - all the rooms were funky and it is a pet friendly place. We got upgraded to a king size bed and the room had a great view. It was very clean and the staff was absolutely great! They were all so helpful. There is a complimentary evening wine and beer social time - we met some great people and watched the fortune teller do her magic. Right next door is an Irish Pub called Irish Bank - it is great! Apr 7 2008 	Mixed experience at the Triton	I stayed at the Triton for 4 nights, and there are some really great things about the hotel but also some that make it a bit less than great. First up, if you are staying there, make sure you ask for a quiet room away from the garbage trucks. On my first night I was awakened at 3am by horrendous noise. Garbage collection lasts about 30 minutes, and it was hard to get back to sleep afterwards. When I spoke to the front desk about it, just wondering what the noise had been, they immediately moved me to another room, overlooking Bush St and much quieter (there were no noise problems on any other night I was there). They did concede that the garbage collection noise is a major and ongoing problem in the hotel.The room I was moved to was smaller than the first one, but it was generally fine. It was a 'Zen Den', which is one of the smaller categories of room, and there really is no spare space at all, but that wasn't a huge problem. If you want to do yoga in your room or anything, there's no space! It was so small the bathroom didn't even have a bath tub - something they didn't tell me at check in.Nice touches in the room: an iPod player. Fantastic to be able to hear my own music in the hotel room.Huge flat screen TV - but I didn't ever use it. There had been a picture taken down from the wall, and there were clumps of plaster missing from the wall - but it hadn't been repaired, so it looked pretty crappy!hey also claim to have 'internet access on the TV'. Mine didn't work, and they had no technical support at all - front desk admitted they didn't know how to work it, because 'most guests had their own laptops'. On the whole, staff were very helpful, responding promptly to queries. There's quite a variety of people on the desks, so it's often different people there - makes it a bit anonymous.Overall, the hotel seemed unable to make up its mind whether it was trying for 'rock n roll cool' or 'new age zen hipness'. Loud music pumping outside the front door on the street and in the elevators; bright garish colours, party time with the wine in the lobby at 6pm, versus organic cotton sheets, free tarot readings in the lobby... It was all a bit mixed up in terms of what the Hotel's identity was.But on the whole it's fine: the location is excellent - opposite the Chinatown gate, near Union Square, short walk to all public transport and attractions. And next door is the outstanding Cafe de la Press - I ate dinner there twice, and had breakfast there every day. Really good food, reasonably priced, excellent atmosphere, good for people-watching. Would I stay at the Triton again? Probably not, there are other boutique hotels that I prefer, but many people will find it an exciting and pretty hip place to stay.

Mar 20 2008 	Great stay at the Triton!	After reading several of the reviews here, I was a bit concerned that I may not enjoy my stay at the Hotel Triton. There was no need for concern as long as one is prepared to make the right requests. The staff could not have been more pleasant and accommodating. Nick at the front desk made sure I got a quiet room...the most quiet ones face an inner atrium. No view, but perfectly quiet, otherwise you'd face some busy streets or worse yet, an alley with garbage trucks emptying their loads early mornings. As an Kimpton In-Touch loyalty member, I received some bonus amenities- a bottle of vitamin water and a can of some dried cranberries, banana chips, and nut mixture, even a personalized letter from the desk manager welcoming me, a very nice touch!Gemelli, the bellman, was terrific- he retrieved new card keys when mine didn't work, got ice, explained the new flatscreen tv, etc. He always called me by name and was just overall gracious, as were all the staff I encountered.The room was small, but whimsically decorated. The queen bed was extremely comfortable, bathroom included only a shower which was fine by me. Wine hour from 5-6 was great, nice to chat with other guests, repours generously given by the director of sales for the hotel. Yes, this is a different type of hotel, not the staid business kind, but lots of fun and well-kept.

Feb 12 2008 	Cool trendy great location	The Hotel Triton is a very unique hotel with some cool features that suit people who are tired of the monotonous lodging choices. My wife and I spent a weekend there and really enjoyed our stay. When you walk into the lobby you'll think you're in a trendy night club. Lots of different colors and cool/colorful lighting accented with eclectic furniture. The rooms the same style.....modern and trendy. They are a little small but we didn't mind at all since most our time was spent enjoying San Francisco. The things we liked about the hotel:- The overall style. It's definitely a cool place to stay- Complimentary happy hours. The first night we had a drink in the lobby while a DJ played before dinner. You don't get that at other hotels.- Service was great. - Location Some cons:- The free wireless internet. Yes, its free but very slow. You have to pay for premium service but I think that is the only service that works.- The rooms are on the small side, but like I said that wasn't a big deal for us.Overall, if you're up for something trendy, modern, and exciting the Hotel Triton is right up your alley.

Feb 7 2008 	San Francisco Boutique Hotel	Hotel Triton is somewhere I had been wanting to stay for a while and fortunately, a business trip came up that would cover the cost. Yay!The hotel is on the south edge of China Town on the corner or Bush & Grant. Great location, easy access to taxis and public transport.The lobby is very cool with an eclectic mix of furnishings and color. I was upgraded from I don't know what to a king size bed on the 7th floor on the Bush side of the bldg. My co-worker was in a "daybed" on the 3rd floor on the Grant side. He said there was quite a bit of street noise and had a hard time sleeping through it. My room seemed to workout pretty nicely. No street noise, but I did turn on the fan for some "white noise". The room was pretty modest in size, but very quaintly decorated. I loved it. The bathroom needs some shelving/wall storage next to the sink. The bathroom is small and counter space is minimal, so shelving would have helped. Towels are great - plentiful and fluffy. The TV is pretty small. Someone in another review mentioned a flat screen TV being a good addition and I agree. The honor bar had some good stuff in it, but high prices as typical for something like that.The business center is a desk next to the check-in counter. Very fast and nice computer though - at $5.99 for 15 minutes of internet time. Doooh....In the morning, there is complimentary coffe/tea in the lobby. No food. My teenage daughter would love. I would return again....if I could afford it. ;-)

Feb 4 2008	A fun favorite	I love the Hotel Triton! The location is perfect for a weekend getaway in S.F. Immeditaly in front of the gates of Chinatown, it's a short walk downt he street to Union Square. The staff is very friendly and helpful. They make great concierges. I;ve stayed in a few rooms here but loved the Jerry Garcia Suite most. Great Tub!Just around the corner Belden Lane is tucked away. A great spot if you want a little French Quarter dining. One of the few outdoor dinner spots in the city.Triton honors the Kimpton happy hour and the guests have wine and visit in the lobby. The hotel is pet friendly & there are water dishes near the door.This is a really fun place to stay!

Jan 26 2008 	Great hotel in an excellent location	I booked at the last minute through Priceline and paid $75 per night (versus their standard rate of $200 per night). The hotel is about 5 minutes walk from Union Square and Market Street and also about the same distance from the Montgomery Street BART station. It was about ten minutes to the Ferry building/Embarcadero and also 10-15 minutes through Chinatown to North Beach and the Italian restaurants.Having booked on Priceline for such a low amount I wasn't expectlng much, but was given an excellent room on the 6th floor. I didn't have any problem with street noise as mentioned in earlier posts. The room was small, with a queen bed and not a lot of room around, but it was more than enough for me. The bathroom was equally cozy, with just a shower although it was well-kept and clean, with Aveda shampoo and lotions too. The sink was in the bathroom; other posts suggest that in some rooms the sink is outside of the bathroom. The room was well-furnished and clean although I think if they replaced the large cathode ray television with an LCD screen it could then be wall-mounted and the hotel could do away with the large television-and-minibar-containing cupboard, which dominates the small room. Other highlights include a zebra-striped bathrobe (the black stripes on mine were purple, presumably as a result of bleaching while washing), an iPod docking station, reliable WiFi, clean, comfortable white bedding and also the wine/beer hour from 5-6pm. This was really nice to take a couple of beers up to the room after spending the day walking around San Francisco.I had breakfast at the adjacent Cafe de la Presse which attempts to recreate the ambiance and service of a Parisian cafe, with prices to match.I think the rack rate charged is too much for this hotel, but if I were to be assigned it again through Priceline or Hotwire then I'd be more than happy.

Jan 17 2008	Shortest stay ever! But liked every minute.	My boyfriend and I live in SF, but due to a scheduling snafu over the holidays (too many parents in town at the same time) we found ourselves in need of a hotel for one night. That said, the location is fabulous if you are visiting from out of town.

Dec 31 2007 	Hotel Triton Funky (in a good way)	The hotel Triton is located literally next door to China Town. The decor is ultra funky and the people at the desk were not only really helpful, but also friendly. The downside: the rooms are VERY small, and our particular room had a view of an inner courtyard that we could never figure out how to get to. Other rooms had an outside view to the street and Chinatown. The coffee in the morning is good but there is no breakfast or even a snack to go with said coffee. Dec 27 2007 	A sweet suite!	My husband and I stayed at the Hotel Triton on our wedding night; we were married in San Francisco and wanted to stay over in the city before embarking on our honeymoon (we're locals). We'd heard great things about the Triton from friends, and everything we heard was met or surpassed. The Triton was friendly, accommodating, quiet, and wholly unique. The room we had was beautifully furnished in hip, offbeat decor, and we didn't hear any noise from the street below when we went to bed. Furthermore the staff were very friendly when we checked in and checked out, and they left us a sweet letter in our suite congratulating us on our marriage and offered us free drinks. They also carry Aveda bath products, which is a definite plus! That said, this hotel is definitely for the 20-30 something set, I think. It has a younger vibe; they have a DJ playing house music downstairs during their complimentary wine hour in the afternoons. This is not to say that those of other generations will not appreciate the Triton; it is uniquely San Francisco in a lot of ways.

Nov 21 2007 	Loved it!	I read plenty of reviews of this hotel before booking it. Many of the reviews complained about the room size and the noise. I decided to ask for a room away from the elevator, alley, and on a higher floor. My stay was wonderful! The room was very nice and clean, and it was not like a sardine can as others have suggested. The size was just fine for my husband and me, and we enjoyed it. I noticed someone said the bathrooms have showers only, but ours was just a regular room and we had a bath/shower combo. Bathroom was stocked with Aveda products (small, travel sizes of course), and the mini bar had lots to choose from. True, there is no bar or restaurant in the hotel, but right next door is a little cafe where you can get wine, pastries, and other food. Plus there are tons of other places nearby. It is located in Union Square right across from the China Town gate--perfect location! Overall the decor and hotel condition is a little old-seeming, but it was not bad. We stayed just 2 nights, and I have no complaints. I did not need ear plugs, but it's a good idea to bring them "just in case" when staying in a city if you're a light sleeper. The one bad thing is that there was a sign on the inside of our door that mentioned the dangers of lead (can't remember for sure but I believe it was lead) in the building. I think it said something about not having prolonged exposure to it. I wasn't too happy about that, but since we were only there 2 nights I figured it would be o.k.Overall, a great experience.

Oct 29 2007 	Boutique past its best	The Hotel Triton in Grant Avenue downtown San Francisco promises to be a fantastic boutique hotel experience to counter the usual Holiday Inn or Marriott experience. Location-wise it could not be better, located just a block or so from Union Square, though I suspect the nouveau boutique reviews were written a while back. The $ rate was good for the location, though (read on) I guess you get what you pay for.... The unique hotel decor is entertaining but a little tired. It has little in the way of facilities: there's no bar or restaurant, though there are loads in the neighbourhood. I was overcharged for the minibar and the movies and had to have it corrected. My room was small and poorly lit. The free WiFi signal was so bad in the room I had to take my laptop to reception to work - there's no hard-wired broadband in the rooms. My "view" was hugely unattractive and of the side-street garbage bins and local restaurant staff puffing their cigarettes, but I was out all day and most evenings so not the end of the world. 1st night I was woken at 3.10 am by the hotel alarm clock, which to be honest I hadn't checked but was incorrectly set by 6 hours. 2nd night I was woken by next door's restaurants emptying hundreds of glass bottles into the bins one-by-one between 2.00 and 3.00 am. Every night I was woken between 5.00 and 6.00 am by the garbage collection trucks. Lousy experience - I'll never stay there again and don't recommend it, as there are so many better San Francisco hotels these days.

Oct 3 2007 	can't wait to come back!!!	I stayed at the Triton with 3 other girls for a dental convention from September 26-30. Our hotel was booked through the ADA but I picked it out because I thought it looked like fun. From the second we got there to the second we left we were treated like old friends. Remember the old saying, treat others the way you would like to be treated. If you walk into any hotel with an attitude or a chip on your shoulder you're probably going to get the same in return... and ya know what? Ya probably deserve it. Anything we needed they were right on it. They made dinner reservations for us on a few occasions and if we needed anything else they took care of it immediately. I didn't seem to need anything though. There wasn't a thing wrong with the room, the beds were comfortable, and the room was clean. Anyone that complains about the room size is just being a pain in the rear. you think that's small? Go to Europe! If you want a bigger room go stay at a $400 a night hotel! Who cares! I'm not 500 pounds so I had a fine time getting around with my roommate and I don't plan to be in the room but to sleep anyway so that shouldn't even matter. I loved the fresh cookies and wine offered. All free. I also thought the complimentary massages and tarot card readings were cool. It's dog friendly which is nice for those who need it. But I didn't see one trace of any animals the whole time I was there. It's located in a great area, right across the street from China Town. And for those who complain about the noise, get over it! IT'S A CITY PEOPLE!, there is going to be street noise. I slept like a baby. You think thats bad... go to New York!! If you want 100% absolute quite go stay in a bed and breakfast in the mountains of Montana! Gee, some of these other reviews really errked me! At any rate, this is a great hotel, there is a fantastic pub around the corner called the Irish Bank, ask for Mark, tell him Alicia sent ya. I can't wait to go back and I am definatly staying at the Triton! Oh and just a note for you single girls out there..... there is no place on earth better to meet single STRAIGHT men! :)

Sep 15 2007 	Never again.	We love boutique hotels until we stayed at the Triton. The Triton is not a boutique but rather a budget hotel. We paid $181 a night with taxes. Sep 13 2007	I enjoyed my stay and the hotel but some of the staff do have an attitude.	I got a really good deal thru priceline ($80 a night) and my request for a quiet room was honored. I would never decorate my own place with a zebra-striped headboard, but it was fine for a few days in my room. I can also see how more than 1 person in my room could become uncomfortable. There places to eat close by (i.e. a Starbucks across the street), so food was easy for me to get.The cons were most of the people who worked there. Where the courtesey they pay you to have in hospitality? Where's your SF pride? Such a great city. You have so much to be proud of! Not the friendliest staff or the most helpful. I think I met one nice person behind the counter. They put cookies out in the afternoon and they'd good.I probably wouldn't return to this hotel unless they have a major customer service overhaul and mainly b/c I didn't prefer the union square/chinatown area. The remaining nights were were moved to a King room which was still small but a little better for 2 people.The room service option was a French restaurant next door and the menu was very limited in terms of options and types of options.
